description: Transmitting sensitive information over unencrypted public Wi-Fi networks exposes personal or company data to eavesdroppers who can intercept login credentials and private communications; this risk is especially high when traffic volume and connections per second spike without encryption monitoring.

Allowing employees to use weak or easily guessable passwords for critical accounts increases the risk of unauthorized access and credential stuffing attacks; password compromise incidents often correlate with unusual authentication attempts per second and elevated login failure rates.

Not requiring two-factor authentication (2FA) for accessing sensitive systems leaves accounts vulnerable to compromise if passwords are leaked or phished; absence of 2FA can be detected by an unusually low rate of multi-factor challenge responses per authentication session.

Publishing API keys or secret credentials in public repositories makes it possible for malicious actors to access protected backend systems or data; spikes in API calls per second and request rates can reveal such leaks during traffic volume analysis.

Storing backup files with sensitive data without any encryption exposes confidential information if physical drives are lost, stolen, or improperly discarded; this vulnerability can be monitored through backup transfer throughput and unauthorized device connection counts per hour.

Granting all employees access to sensitive customer data, regardless of their role, increases the risk of both accidental and intentional misuse of information; data access events per minute and concurrent sessions metrics help identify over-privileged accounts.

Relying on outdated software that lacks security updates makes systems vulnerable to exploitation by attackers who target known vulnerabilities; look for spikes in exploit attempts per second and increased traffic volume to unpatched endpoints.

Failing to publish or update a privacy policy leaves users unaware of how their data is collected, used, or shared, undermining trust and legal compliance; low web page request rates for the policy page and minimal user engagement metrics can signal this issue.

Permitting unrestricted use of USB drives on company computers can result in data theft or malware infections through unauthorized or compromised devices; monitor USB connection counts per hour and data transfer volume for anomalies.

Allowing browsers to save passwords in plain text or without strong encryption can lead to credential theft if the device is compromised; abnormal increases in local storage read/write operations or password retrieval events per minute may indicate this risk.

Leaving known security vulnerabilities unpatched exposes systems to exploitation and increases the likelihood of a data breach; increased scanning attempts per second and unusual traffic volume to vulnerable services are key indicators.

Collecting excessive personal data from users that is not necessary for service provision increases the risk of privacy violations if breached; track form submission volumes and data field usage per request to detect over-collection.

Failing to change default usernames and passwords on devices and applications makes it easy for attackers to gain unauthorized access; monitor failed login attempts per second against default credentials to identify such exposures.

Storing user data without encryption at rest allows anyone with physical or administrative access to view sensitive information; disk read throughput and unauthorized file access counts per minute can help detect unencrypted data exposure.

Transmitting sensitive data without encryption in transit makes it vulnerable to interception by attackers during transfer; monitoring TLS handshake failures per second and cleartext traffic volume helps uncover this issue.

Having no clear data retention policy means personal data may be kept indefinitely, increasing exposure in the event of a breach; retention growth rates and storage volume metrics per week can highlight compliance gaps.

Improper disposal of hardware, such as failing to wipe hard drives before discarding, can result in data leaks from discarded devices; track decommissioned device counts per month and data wipe completion rates.

Lack of log monitoring allows unauthorized access or suspicious activity to go undetected within critical systems; low log ingestion rates and minimal alert triggers per hour can signal this deficiency.

Not requesting or recording user consent before placing cookies on their devices undermines user privacy and regulatory compliance; cookie banner display counts versus acceptance events per session can indicate missing consent flows.

Tracking user activity online without explicit consent raises serious privacy concerns and can breach legal regulations; spikes in pageview tracking events per second and analytics collection volume should be audited.

Requesting access to device cameras or microphones without clear disclosure or consent can result in unauthorized recordings of private activities; monitor media device access events per session and connection initiation rates.

Storing sensitive data in public or poorly secured cloud storage increases the chance of unauthorized access by external parties; unusual storage request rates and public bucket access metrics per hour signal exposure.

Leaving web server directories openly accessible allows attackers to browse, download, or tamper with files not meant for public viewing; directory listing request volume and 404 error rate per second are key metrics to watch.

Allowing users to reuse passwords across different systems increases the risk of widespread account compromise if one account is breached; measure password reuse attempts per user and cross-system login rates.

Devices lacking secure boot can be tampered with to load malicious software at startup, threatening the privacy of data stored or processed; unusual firmware load attempts per minute and boot time deviations should be monitored.

Storing and sharing raw data without anonymizing or pseudonymizing personal details risks direct identification of individuals if leaked; track dataset download volume and record access counts per user.
Sending sensitive business or personal information over unencrypted email exposes it to interception or unauthorized reading; monitor email transmission rates, TLS usage, and cleartext email volume.

Sharing user data with third-party partners or vendors without proper consent or contracts can lead to unexpected data misuse; measure data export volume and API call counts to external domains per minute.

Allowing remote access to critical systems without adequate monitoring or restrictions can enable unauthorized intrusions and data theft; track remote login attempts per second and session duration anomalies.
Not keeping access logs prevents investigation and identification of unauthorized access or potential data breaches; low log retention volumes and alert counts per day are signals of this gap.

Oversharing personal information on social media, such as birth dates and locations, can make users more vulnerable to social engineering attacks; social post frequency and metadata exposure rates per post should be reviewed.
Relying on weak or easily guessed security questions as part of account recovery makes it easier for attackers to gain account access; monitor recovery attempts per user and question failure rates.

Collecting and sharing location data from user devices without explicit and informed consent can lead to tracking and privacy invasion; track GPS coordinate transmissions per session and location request counts.
Lack of device lockout mechanisms allows unauthorized users to access sensitive data on lost or unattended devices; measure failed unlock attempts per hour and auto-lock activation frequency.
Transferring files without using secure file transfer protocols can expose sensitive data to interception during transmission; monitor SFTP versus FTP usage counts and unencrypted transfer volume.

Embedding confidential information in file metadata, such as document author or editing history, can unintentionally expose private details when shared; track metadata extraction requests per file and abnormal read/write rates.

Not conducting regular security audits can result in unnoticed vulnerabilities or privacy gaps within company systems; low audit frequency and minimal vulnerability scan counts per quarter highlight this risk.

Connecting insecure Internet of Things (IoT) devices to corporate networks exposes sensitive environments to potential remote attacks; monitor device connection volume per second and unrecognized device join rates.

Including sensitive information, such as session IDs or user details, in URL parameters may inadvertently expose data through browser history or logs; track URL parameter usage counts and referer header volumes.
Allowing remote employees to access company systems without requiring VPN use exposes internal networks to external threats; measure VPN connection rates per minute versus direct access attempts.
Displaying sensitive information on shared screens or public monitors risks unauthorized viewing by bystanders; monitor screen share session counts and average view duration per session.

Falling victim to phishing attacks, such as clicking on malicious links or opening dangerous attachments, can compromise personal or corporate data; track phishing email click-through rates and report counts per day.
Installing unapproved applications on company devices can introduce malware or lead to unauthorized data access; monitor application install events per device and unrecognized app launch rates.

Failure to provide privacy awareness training to employees increases the likelihood of unintentional breaches or risky behaviors; low training completion rates and minimal quiz participation per cohort are red flags.
Leaving inactive or terminated user accounts enabled can allow former employees or attackers to access internal systems; track account deactivation delays and inactive login counts per month.

Storing confidential physical documents in unlocked cabinets or open offices risks loss or theft by unauthorized individuals; measure cabinet access counts per day and unauthorized entry attempts per hour.

Retaining outdated or unnecessary personal data increases exposure in the event of a breach and complicates compliance with data minimization requirements; monitor data retention volume growth and record age distribution.

Lacking a formal breach notification process results in delays or failures to inform users about incidents affecting their data privacy; measure notification delay times and incident response counts per quarter.

Failing to enable or enforce encryption on mobile devices used for work puts sensitive data at risk if devices are lost or stolen; track device encryption status rates and unauthorized data access attempts per device.

Transferring data across international borders without proper safeguards or legal agreements can violate privacy laws and expose data to foreign surveillance; monitor cross-border traffic volume and external endpoint connection counts.

Not restricting system or data access based on employee roles leads to excessive access privileges and increases breach risk; track role change events per user and concurrent permission elevation counts.

Operating without a Data Loss Prevention (DLP) system allows sensitive data to leave the organization unnoticed through emails, uploads, or removable drives; measure DLP event capture rates and blocked transfer volume.

Setting online calendar events as public by default may inadvertently expose meeting details or participantsâ€™ identities; monitor public event creation counts per week and participant list access rates.

Failing to regularly review user access rights increases the chance that unauthorized personnel retain access to sensitive information; track access review frequency and stale permission counts per cycle.

Inadequately classifying data types, such as treating confidential and public data the same, increases risk of accidental disclosure; measure classification event counts and misclassification rates per dataset.
Lacking an incident response plan hinders effective management and containment of data privacy breaches when they occur; monitor incident drill frequency and response time metrics per incident.
Processing payment transactions without using secure, encrypted channels exposes financial data to interception and fraud; track payment gateway request volume and TLS handshake success rates.

Embedding third-party tracking pixels on websites without user awareness allows external entities to monitor user behavior across sites; measure pixel load events per pageview and third-party request volume.

Not providing parental control options on apps or websites aimed at children can lead to exposure of minors to inappropriate content or data misuse; monitor feature enablement rates and blocked content request counts.

Leaving Bluetooth connections open and discoverable makes devices more susceptible to unauthorized pairing and data interception; measure Bluetooth scan events per minute and unauthorized pairing attempts.

Collecting or processing biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial recognition, without explicit user consent presents major privacy risks and legal liabilities; track biometric capture counts and consent event rates.

Requesting overly broad permissions on mobile apps, such as access to contacts, messages, or location, can enable excessive and unnecessary data collection; monitor permission grant counts and data usage volume per permission.

Storing data in unsecured or poorly maintained physical locations, such as unlocked server rooms, increases the risk of unauthorized access; measure room entry events per hour and unauthorized access alarms.
Not verifying the integrity of stored or transmitted data can allow tampering or corruption to go undetected; track checksum failure rates and data integrity verification event counts.

Leaving access tokens or session cookies unprotected in local storage allows attackers to impersonate users if a device is compromised; monitor token usage counts per session and unauthorized token replay attempts.

Failing to perform privacy impact assessments before launching new products or services can result in overlooked risks and regulatory breaches; measure PIA completion rates and identified issue counts per project.

Allowing uncontrolled use of portable storage devices, such as USB drives, raises the risk of data loss, theft, or malware introduction; monitor portable device connection rates and file transfer volume per device.
Not deploying a secure email gateway leaves organizations exposed to phishing, spam, and malware-laden emails; track email filtering rates and malicious message counts per day.

Configuring access rights incorrectly, such as granting admin privileges to regular users, makes it easier for attackers to escalate privileges and access sensitive data; measure privilege change events and unauthorized privilege use per hour.
Employees using unapproved cloud services (shadow IT) can store company data in insecure environments without oversight; monitor external cloud API call volume and unknown service usage rates.
Not clearly communicating how user data is collected, processed, and shared leads to lack of transparency and potential distrust; track privacy page visit counts and user feedback submission rates.

Sharing sensitive data with third-party vendors or service providers without proper vetting can result in uncontrolled data dissemination; measure vendor data exchange volume and contract compliance checks per quarter.
Inadequate procedures for verifying user identity before disclosing personal information can lead to unauthorized data disclosure; monitor identity verification attempts per minute and failure rates.
Not having a policy for lost or stolen devices may delay action and increase the risk of data exposure; track incident reports per lost device and policy enforcement metrics.
Retaining more personal data than necessary for business operations or legal compliance increases risk if breached; monitor data minimization compliance rates and storage volume per data category.
Failing to properly secure cookies, such as not marking them as HttpOnly or Secure, increases risk of session hijacking; track cookie flag setting rates and hijack attempt counts.

Allowing remote desktop access without requiring strong authentication or limiting access to known IP addresses exposes internal systems to attack; measure RDP connection attempts per second and failed authentication rates.

Voice assistant devices recording audio conversations without clearly informing users can violate privacy expectations in private spaces; track microphone activation counts and recording duration metrics.

Relying on insecure or outdated software dependencies within applications increases the risk of vulnerabilities that could lead to data leaks; monitor dependency vulnerability scan rates and outdated library usage counts.

Not providing users with a way to export or delete their personal data makes it harder to comply with data protection laws and user rights; track data export request volumes and deletion completion rates.

Susceptibility to social engineering, such as staff giving out information over the phone without verification, can lead to data leaks; measure incident report rates per social engineering attempt and call volume anomalies.

Transferring confidential data over unsecured channels, such as FTP or HTTP, exposes it to interception and unauthorized access; monitor transfer protocol usage counts and unencrypted data volume per day.
Setting file sharing or collaboration platforms to public by default may result in unintended data exposure to unauthorized users; track public share link creation rates and download counts per link.
Deploying camera surveillance in workplaces without adequate notice or policies can violate employee privacy rights; monitor camera activation events per hour and recorded footage access counts.

Failing to physically secure servers, such as leaving data centers unlocked, makes it easy for intruders to access hardware and stored data; measure door access event counts and unauthorized entry alarms.

Allowing installation of software updates from unverified sources may introduce malware or backdoors that compromise data; track update origin verification failure rates and untrusted package installation events.

Using customer contact information for purposes other than originally stated, such as unsolicited marketing, breaches user trust and privacy expectations; monitor email send volumes and unsubscribe rates.
Not providing regular security training for employees increases the risk that staff will inadvertently compromise data privacy; track training enrollment rates and phishing simulation failure counts.

Failing to assign clear data ownership and responsibility can cause confusion and increase the chance of data privacy oversights; measure ownership assignment completion rates and unresolved incident counts.

Allowing password recovery processes that can be bypassed with publicly available information (such as birthdates) exposes accounts to takeover; monitor recovery event counts and bypass attempt rates.
Integrating third-party apps into core systems without sufficient review can introduce privacy risks through uncontrolled data sharing; track integration request volumes and review completion rates.
Using instant messaging tools that do not encrypt communications end-to-end exposes conversations to interception; measure message send rates and unencrypted payload volume.
Failing to comply with GDPR or other relevant privacy regulations can result in legal penalties and significant data privacy violations; monitor compliance audit counts and violation incident rates.

Allowing use of analytics tools that collect more data than necessary without informing users can breach privacy expectations and laws; track analytics event volume per user and data retention durations.
Recording phone calls or video conferences without notifying participants can violate laws and individual privacy rights; measure recording start counts per session and consent event rates.

Allowing employees to use personal devices for business communications and data storage without enforcing security controls can result in company data loss; monitor bring-your-own-device connection counts and policy violation events.
Not providing privacy settings for users to control visibility of their data or activity can expose information more broadly than intended; track setting change counts and default visibility metrics.
Sending marketing emails to users who have not opted in or who have withdrawn consent breaches privacy and may violate regulations; measure opt-in rates and complaint counts per campaign.
Sharing user data with law enforcement without legal process or transparency can erode user trust and privacy; monitor lawful request volumes and transparency report counts.
Storing archives or backups containing sensitive data in insecure locations increases the likelihood of unauthorized access; track archive mount events and access logs per backup instance.
